text.headline: New Facts and Old Fictions
text.text:
The factual information in Münster’s Cosmographia was mostly about inhabitants and tradable resources. Europeans at this time had assumptions about civilizational hierarchies, and often spoke disparagingly of cultures and faiths different to their own.

At the same time as  Münster’s Cosmographia introduced new facts, it also reproduced persistent fictions about Southeast Asia.

text.headline: Sumatra appears
text.text: The parts of Münster’s Cosmographia to deal with “India Extrema” [loosely, India and Beyond] incorporated updated factual information about the region. In his XIX Tabula (Nineteenth Map), a large island now appears as separate from, and lying to the southwest of, the peninsula containing Malaqua [Malacca].  Confusingly, this is named both Taprobana and Sumatra. It is now accepted that Taprobana was the name for contemporary Sri Lanka. The textual description in Cosmographia of this island also describes historical features of Sri Lanka.

text.headline: The Emporia of Malacca
text.text:
Münster’s Cosmographia also reports on the trading importance of Malaqua, which by the time he wrote in 1544 had been “subdued” by the Portuguese admiral Afonso de Albuquerque. This is how Münster described Malacca:

 “Malaqua, has a goodly & commodious haven: by reason whereof, more ships arrive there than in any other place: bringing with them spices and other merchandise in great abundance.” He also mentions other resources the Malay peninsula “brought forth” including “spices, saunders [red sandalwood], tin, elephants, horses, sheep [likely goats], wild ox, peacocks, and such other kinds of beasts”. He reports that it was dangerous to walk the city at night and because of this “the merchant strangers [sea traders] lodge not out of their ships”.

text.headline: Malacca in the Malay Annals
text.text:
The Malay Annals (originally Sulalatus Salatin or Geneaology of Kings), composed between the 15th and 16th centuries by an unknown author, includes a description of Malacca. The Annals reports it had: 

“acquired a numerous population, and merchants resorted to it from every quarter….It became noted in every country…. All the merchants likewise, whether from above or under the wind, frequented Malaca… all the Arabs gave it the name of Malakat, or the mart for collecting all merchants; for many different races of merchants frequented it, and all its great men were extremely just in all their proceedings….and equitable in the protection of all strangers”.

text.headline: The Spice Islands
text.text:
Münster’s map includes the islands of Moluca, Taranate, and Gilolo vel Siloli, what came to be called the “Spice Islands.” The Banda Islands are described by Münster but not shown on his map.

“The soil … bringeth forth nothing but nutmegs…. The stalk or body of the nutmeg tree, is not much unlike the stalk of a peach tree, bringing forth like branches and leaves, but somewhat narrower. Before these nuts be ripe, the mace creeps on the tree, like a flourishing rose. And when the nutmeg wax ripe, the mace embraces it round about. And so they gather both together in commune, at a time appointed [October].”

text.headline: Nutmeg
text.text: Insvlae Molvccae [Molucca Islands] is a 1598 map by the Dutch merchant Jan Huygen van Linschoten (1563-1611), and engraved by William Rogers. The inset explains that these Islands are “most famous because of the vast abundance of spices they send to the whole world” and points the reader to the life-like drawings of these spices, including nutmeg and mace,depicted at the bottom of the map, and until the mid 19th century sourced only from the Banda Islands.

text.headline: Sea monsters real and imagined
text.text:
Münster also depicts and describes various fantatical sea monsters:

“In the sea about this island, are often times seen the great monstrous fishes, & kind of Whales, called Balene, which bring many incommodities [inconvenience] to the inhabitants. They are of such monstrous bigness, that when they approach to the Sea banks, they seem like unto hills: they have rough backs full of sharp pricks. And except men walk very warily by the sea banks, they are in danger to be suddenly swallowed up by these monsters. Some of them have so great and wide mouths, that they sometimes swallow whole ships with the men.”

A fully fictional mermaid, here in the two tail form, also appears in the ocean.

text.headline: Sea monsters real and imagined
text.text: Die Laender Asie nach ihrer Gelegenheit biss in Indiam, werden in dieser Tafeln verzeichnet [Asia including countries after the borders of India] is a 1550 German language version of Münster’s Cosmographia, with the maps hand-tinted.  In Antiquity the Roman naturalist Pliny the Elder argued that monstrosities of nature formed readily in water as a result of its nutrients and liquid nature. Mermaids were often seen as dangerous creatures of the sea, because seductive, and able to call to sailors and so shipwreck vessels.

text.headline: The “Plinian races”
text.text: This version of Ptolemy’s map in Münster’s Cosmographia is surrounded with “monsters.” These fantastical creatures can be traced back to accounts given by the Roman naturalist Pliny the Elder in this Historia naturalis. These “Plinian races” were based almost entirely on second-hand accounts, and most certainly mixed fact and fiction.

text.headline: The “Plinian races”
text.text: The 1360 memoir The Travels of Sir John Mandeville, circulated widely and in many European languages, contained descriptions of these creatures, as did Sebastian Münster’s Cosmographia (1544).
